sub_topic: Calculating the enthalpy and entropy of inorganic reactions
message_1: What is the change in enthalpy and entropy for the reaction of 2 moles of sodium hydroxide with 1 mole of sulfuric acid to form 2 moles of water and 1 mole of sodium sulfate, assuming standard conditions?
message_2:
To calculate the change in enthalpy (ΔH) and entropy (ΔS) for the given reaction, we need to know the standard enthalpies of formation (ΔHf°) and standard entropies (S°) for each substance involved in the reaction. The reaction is as follows:

2 NaOH (aq) + H2SO4 (aq) → 2 H2O (l) + Na2SO4 (aq)

The standard enthalpies of formation (ΔHf°) and standard entropies (S°) for each substance are as follows (in kJ/mol for ΔHf° and J/mol·K for S°):

NaOH (aq): ΔHf° = -469.15 kJ/mol, S° = 57.2 J/mol·K
H2SO4 (aq): ΔHf° = -909.3 kJ/mol, S° = 156.9 J/mol·K
H2O (l): ΔHf° = -285.83 kJ/mol, S° = 69.9 J/mol·K
Na2SO4 (aq): ΔHf° = -1387.1 kJ/mol, S° = 149.1 J/mol·K

First, let's calculate the change in enthalpy (ΔH):

ΔH = [2 × ΔHf°(H2O) + ΔHf°(Na2SO4)] - [2 × ΔHf°(NaOH) + ΔHf°(H2SO4)]

ΔH = [2 × (-285.83) + (-1387.1)] - [2 × (-469.15) + (-909.3)]
ΔH = (-571.66 - 1387.1) - (-938.3 - 909.3)
ΔH = -1958.76 + 1847.6
ΔH = -111.16 kJ/mol

Now, let's calculate the change in entropy (ΔS):

ΔS = [2 × S°(H2O) + S°(Na2SO4)] - [2 × S°(NaOH) + S°(H2SO4)]

ΔS = [2 × 69.9 + 149.1] - [2 × 57.2 + 156.9]
ΔS = (139.8 + 149.1) - (114.4 + 156.9)
ΔS = 288.9 - 271.3
ΔS = 17.6 J/mol·K

So, the change in enthalpy (ΔH) for the reaction is -111.16 kJ/mol, and the change in entropy (ΔS) is 17.6 J/mol·K.
